pros: Benefits, diversity, hybrid, great environment
cons: Nothing really I will say that some jobs need more pay to value their employees.

job_title: Student Life Advisor in Cleveland, OH
pros: Inclusive and family like environment
cons: Procedures and policies can be outdated at times.

pros: Great place to work with career advancement.
cons: Yearly bonuses are not offered.

pros: There's a lot of interesting people who work here and pretty much everyone works for the better of the students. Pretty laid back environment.
cons: Lots of interesting people who work here and not much fresh blood. People tend to come here and stay here which is great if they're great, sucks otherwise. Also, your enjoyment is very campus and even department specific. Your direct supervisor (and their supervisor) makes the difference.

pros: Excellent managers and co-workers, some of the best in the business. Room for advancement. Just a great place to work if you enjoy working with students.
cons: Full-time positions are hard to come by…no one wants to leave which is a good thing. No benefits for part-timers which is to be expected.

review_title: I worked in the marketing dept ages ago
pros: I worked in the marketing dept ages ago (20+ years now) but overall it was a good experience. Lots of bureaucracy and no cutting-edge approaches to PR or marketing, but the college has an amazing mission to bring affordable, accessible care to students. And that's something you can be proud of when you work there.
cons: The marketing approaches could be outdated--20+ years later, they're still using the same CTA and tagline as well as the same outdated graphics.

review_title: Culture can vary department by department
pros: Mission. Good people. Great students.
cons: Not all managers treat their direct reports with respect. It varies department by department

pros: education benefits free food hours
cons: salary hours co workers office environment

review_title: Great place to work but it depends on the department.
pros: I love the people I work with. They genuinely care for the students. Many of these folks could work elsewhere (for higher pay) but choose to work at an urban community college.
cons: Like most institutions of higher education, there is a lot of bureaucracy to navigate.

review_title: Ok if you don’t mind micromanagement
pros: Easy work, great coworkers, close, work life balance, holiday shutdown week in December
cons: Low pay, micromanagement, office politics, competitive, boring work

pros: Tri-C provides good work/life balance
cons: It's difficult to move into other positions

pros: They provide fair pay, job security, and great coworkers. Everyone on campus is a joy to be around, and I never once felt stressed or uneasy while being there.
cons: Things can move a little slow as far as hiring, and position movement goes.

job_title: Work Study Student in Parma, OH
pros: Staff was very easy to work with and was communicative, I had no issues in my time of working there as a work study student
cons: I personally have no complaints

pros: Lots of benefits and perks.
cons: The pay was terrible. Maybe different in other areas, but it was low in my department. The offer was something you'd get fresh out of college, not with years of experience. Was hoping to get my foot in the door and progress through the college, but other offers with more money made me leave. Great place to be though, but the pay just wasn't enough.

pros: CCC is a great place to work.
cons: The salary is lacking. Difficult time keeping staff because of low wages. Very difficult to be promoted.

pros: Union, convenient locations, internal growth
cons: Pay could be increased across the board

pros: Benefits, community involvement, mission to provide affordable job training
cons: Non-union positions may experience burnout

review_title: A good place to work if you like being over worked and under paid
pros: Benefits and time off policy are great. Salary is based on 37.5 hour work week. Paid winter break from Christmas Eve through New Years Day
cons: There is a reason the mascot is a dinosaur. They utilize the most archaic systems and processes. Leaders won’t help even when employees are in a crisis. Pay is not competitive and is incredibly biased. The people at the top are always taken care of but the people at the bottom don’t matter. The college thinks 1% is an acceptable cost of living raise.

review_title: Great place to work- shame it was only part-time
pros: Great environment, people, pay. Good students.
cons: Only part-time available. No benefits or possibility of growth. No stability in how many courses you teach.

pros:
Great benefits 
Flexibility
Team atmosphere
Holidays off
cons: No cons that I can think of

review_title: Depends on the Department and Boss
pros: Closed between Christmas and New Year
cons:
- Only 2 weeks vacation to start (for non-union staff). Must work 5 years to get to 3 years. 
- Low pay
- Yearly raises are 1% or 2%
- Faculty rule the roost. They make great money and whine constantly.

pros: I have found TriC to be an outstanding place to work.
cons: It is difficult to move to Full Time from Part Time.

pros: The student who are there to learn
cons: Unless you know someone at the top you'll never get a full-time position. A worker whose dad is a dean got a job over someone who was more qualified. Now, we have a deadbeat working in the department who says he'll tell the upper management that we are complaining. As an adjunct, I have been teaching for over 10 years at the college. When a full-time opportunity came up I applied but was turned down for the position only to find out the person who got it was friends with board members. It is sad to know how my 10 years of teaching, higher education degree, and excellent performance reviews were passed over by someone who does not have a higher education degree but knows has friends who are board members and in upper management. BTY - these people also know me.

pros: Benefits, flexible work schedule, great staff
cons: insurance is high, pay could be better

review_title: GOOD PLACE TO WORK if you don’t seek a full-time position
pros: GREAT FACULTY, STUDENTS AND FACILITY.
cons: LOW PAY... THE ADJUNCT PROFESSORS AREN’T EVER CONSIDERED FOR THE POTENTIAL FULL-TIME POSITION. YOU WILL NOT BE CALLED FOR AN INTERVIEW TO SEE WHAT YOU GOT IN SPITE OF YOU WORKED FOR THEIR DEPARTMENT AS AN ADJUNCT for a decade with awesome reviews from your colleagues, best evaluation report and great feedback from your students. IF YOU ARE SEEKING TO BECOME A FULL-TIME POSITION DON’T WASTE YOUR TIME AS AN ADJUNCT FACULTY.

pros: Great place to work at
cons: Over bloated. Interview process is archaic

job_title: Program Assistant in Highland Hills, OH
pros:
most positions allow you to be off weekends
professional environment many educated employees 
reputable company to work for.
cons: not a lot of room for growth, departments usually already know who they want to hire for a position is listed. Very political job all about who you know for the good positions.

pros: great environment, nice working culture
cons: none at the moment thank you

pros: Tri-C offers so many opportunities to join committees of interest such as Employee Resource Groups, take leadership and diversity courses to prepare you as a current or future leader through HR trainings, participate in annual or bi-annual trainings and in-house development and team building days, and also demonstrates their gratitude to you be provinding recognitions large and small such as the Mandel and Lift programs, Convocation awards, but also Tri-C Famous Spotlights.
cons: It's such a large institution, sometimes good ideas run faster than they can be executed properly, such as the cart before the horse metaphor. However, the bright side is Tri- C is a an organization that says "yes, and", opposed to "no we've always done it that way".

pros: Friendly colleagues, excellent retirement benefits and PTO
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement in some departments

pros: The pay is descent. The contribute to retirement.
cons: Treat adjunct as disposable employees.

job_title: Customer Service- Library Front Line and Open Computer Lab in Warrensville Heights, OH
pros:
Some really good managers
Loved helping students 
Like the diversity
If the job is Union you have some protection.
If the job is non-union then pay is negotiable.
cons:
If union then Pay is not equivalent to work or knowledge expected. 
If job is Not union then it’s an “at will” job. 
Really hard to move to a better paying position.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
job_title: Digital Media Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros:
37.5 hour work week
Plenty of vacation and sick time
cons: Things move slowly, initiatives/projects require buy-in from many areas to move forward.

pros: Professional, friendly, employee focused, great!
cons: I have no cons at this time

review_title: pretty deceit place to work at
pros: the people there are great
cons: have some issues at times but who don't

pros: Great benefits, excellent co workers
cons: Little room for growth, lots of politics

review_title: About as good as it gets in Cleveland
pros: Great co-workers and mission of the organization
cons: Very hard to advance your career unless you have family and friends at the top

pros: No micromanagement, they give you liberty as far as you stick to topics included
cons: lack of Outreach for programs, marketing, display of student work, sense of community among peers.

job_title: Assistant Adjunct Professor in Parma, OH
pros: Working Environment, Staff and Pay
cons: Classes can get canceled or switched days before a course starts.

pros: Awesome work environment and supervisors
cons: Part time only and hard to pick up hours

pros: Benefits are good, campuses are nice
cons: Downtown traffic can be a pain.

pros: the online peer tutor is a good part-time, admin people are very helpful and best communication.
cons: the payment per hour is not as we expected

pros: Team environment, caring colleagues, strong mission to help advance student success
cons: Management top heavy, internal processes slow and inefficient

review_title: I enjoyed my time working here!
pros: Great staff and good benefits
cons: None, I enjoyed my time here.

job_title: Customer Success Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros: Pay, benefits, time off, nice people
cons: Most positions are union positions

review_title: Nursing =Chaotic.There are good days, but I would say more bad.  You find out policies and rules by getting in trouble.
pros: Love working with students. Student population is a lot of adults and those with a drive to learn.  Many lab resources, it is really amazing.   The new dean is very kind.  Associate dean is very wise.
cons: Nursing is at 3 campuses so faculty are required to go to all campuses.  Some course groups allow you to choose yourself while the others force you to rotate.  I am not a child...let me choose where I want to work.  You can make requests, but it really doesn't matter.  The new dean is sweet, but overall management does not care about the faculty.

pros: good benefits and pay. good work schedule with 4 days a week and three off.
cons:
poor upper managment, takes forever to get anything done due to the fact that it is a massive bureaucracy. the work enviroment is very chaotic and hostile. the staff is very sneaky and will stab you in the back every chance they get and smile about it.
I would not recomend working for this collage in the cdl program, cant really speak for other departments within the collage but the cdl program is a massive joke. will tell you your doing well right to your face and say worse behind you back to their peers. was told it would have been 2 weeks to a month to start working and it ended up being closer to 3 months.

pros: Affordable education. Various programs for students.
cons: The political climate is unbelievable. The extent to which my supervisor lied to others to make political maneuvers or build childish alliances was surreal. He thought he was so clever; his behavior and lack of ethics was shameful. He chose to flank himself with foolish people who will do anything to keep there jobs because they are not marketable. He knowingly promoted people to positions who would shield him because they don't have educations or the skill set to earn comparable pay elsewhere. His supervisors did very little to protect students or live up to the mission of the college. I recorded conversations where wrongdoing took place. The then program manager is oblivious to the recordings.  Creating a culture where people feel like recording conversations is their only recourse to prove their claims is unhealthy, but what some resort to when working in a code of silence environment.

pros: Great place to work, seems like it actually cares about its employees. Tri-C showed this by offering a generous hourly pay, good benefits for a part-time employee, on the job training, and discounted tuition are just some of the benefits. These are benefits for every employee at the college. The supervisor did their best to make an accommodating schedule to fit employees's lives.  This department had a great work/life balance. As a part-time employee, you have many chances to get over 32 hours per week. Overall, I enjoyed my time at Tri-C, I would have stayed if the opportunity for full-time could have come sooner. I would recommend working there and even consider going back.
cons: Many positions are part-time and even with chances of getting more than part-time hours in a week you may run into the problem of getting completely cut off from work until the next fiscal year.

review_title: The coworkers are the key to it working out
pros: Flexible hours depending on who's on shift, calm temperature controlled work environment. Simple tasks, along the lines of routine cleaning and equipment checkout. Department head is nice and has many connections to help get further in industry.
cons: The position is one that to an extent isn't really too needed. Interaction with students should be done by the studio manager and head of department, as well as the cleaning needs be done by actual cleaning staff. The jobs individually seem to be ones that should be separate, not just tasks thrown into the "student assistant" category. Coworkers are other students, so synergy in the workplace contingent on one being able to handle those classmates. Some of the superiors have questionable commentary that has been borderline racist or misogynistic.

pros: Benefits are decent - healthcare, tuition benefits, good leave accrual, and OPERS retirement...
cons: The college does not operate as one entity, multiple campuses operate separately - makes it unnecessarily chaotic for students who attend more than 1 campus.  The college invests more in its higher level execs than its own students.  Many of these higher level execs don't even report to a campus where students are located, but to a District office completely away from students. The college also relies on an astounding number of grants, seemingly to avoid hard funding various programs that ultimately bring revenue.

review_title: Decent pay for adjunct faculty, plenty of freedom to teach
pros:
The pay is reasonable. If you have a good department coordinator then you get the support you need to be effective teaching your class/es.

If you take the time to search out support from other areas (library, center for learning excellence, etc) then you can utilize the services the college has to offer.
cons: Very little incentive for adjuncts to develop their classes. The time it takes is essentially pro bono. Also, adjuncts are never given access to student evaluations. Not sure what the point of doing them is if you can't learn from them.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Cleveland, OH
pros: The students are wonderful, which makes the work rewarding even as the job is terrible.
cons: The institution is taking advantage of the professional backgrounds and dedication of adjunct faculty - it refuses to pay a professional wage or grant any benefits. As a professional, I find this to be demoralizing and insulting. There is also almost no opportunity to advance to a full-time position. If you can't threaten to leave, you have no leverage.

review_title: Better than average for a college, but lots of turnover and poor communication
pros: Better than average benefits, Easy Access location, Safe enviroment, Friendly staff
cons: Lots of turnover of administrators, tight budgets, staff is very often kept in the dark

review_title: An intersesting, intellectually rewarding experience. I have taught about 80 sections of courses since 1988,
job_title: Adjunct Instructor In History and Sometimes Political Science in Cleveland, OH
pros: My interactions with the students, their diversity, and that Tri-c has students of all ages has greatly added to my great enjoyment of teaching at  Cuyahoga Community College..  The many campus locations also makes the college convient for our studends to attend.  Also I have been impressed the high quality faculy, both full and part time, that make up our teaching team
cons: Some of the very young students often do not apply themeselves..The students in many of the programs are outstanding.

pros:
I cant speak for full-time employees, but part-time adjunct professor is stress-free and you get free reign in your class-room for the most part, aside from hitting all of the learning objectives and curriculum targets.

There is little micromanaging in the mathematics department and I find that the adjunct professors generally get along and help if necessary.
cons:
There is not a lot of direction if you are new to teaching.

The chair is unorganized with their thoughts and schedule, but still really nice

pros: I can't think of any. The reduced tuition isn't worth the abuse you take each day from insulting faculty and unhappy staff.
cons: Unfortunately, there is no one to speak to about issues because the top person in management is crooked and self-serving too. Very political. Nepotism. The most unprofessional group of supposedly intelligent people I've ever dealt with. There is so much backstabbing and lying that you can't trust anyone. Everyone is looking to reach the next level no matter who they step on. Low pay. HR is a joke. Problems are never resolved. Caring for students is lip service. Students don't want to deal with Student Service Depts because the staff is so rude.

pros: The flexibility in my work schedule is great, but it varies by dept., My co-workers/colleagues are very friendly, inviting, and willing to help. There are many employee perks:  FREE tuition for Tri-C classes and discounted tuition for many of it's partner institutions (Tiffin, Franklin, University of Phoenix, etc.) to support continued education; Use of all recreational facilities/pools;  Discounted tickets to various events throughout the Cleveland area. Plus, lots of opportunity for growth, development, and advancement.
cons: Hiring process lacks structure and clear communication of job offer, salary, benefits, etc. OPERS payroll deduction (retirement fund) is rather excessive for part-time employees.

pros: People working there are kind and commited to what they do. It's a large organization with a lot going on. Job is low stress and you won't feel overworked. Might be ok part time job for someone who doesn't want stress or doesn't care about growth.
cons: Pay is low. No chance of a raise, promotion or more responsibilities. Everyone is treated the same regardless of years served. Work can get dry after awhile. No opportunity for growth.

review_title: WARNING! If you're not into drama, keep moving...RUN!
pros: I can't think of any. The only one might be the potential for tuition reimbursement.
cons: Watch your back. Do not socialize with anyone. I have never seen so many unprofessional, backstabbing, suppose to be intellegent, people in my life. Management holds grudges, lies and shows favoritism, along with nepotism. Deans and HR constantly throw the fact that Ohio is an "at-will employer" in your face. The HR person was downright childish in her attempts to instigate and create tension in the department. It was normal for faculty to openly insult students regarding their former high school or neighborhood. The environment is extremely toxic.

pros: They have a huge investment in technology.  Which you can take advantage of.  The mentors within my department have been great.  I enjoy the students and challenges presented to them.  They are eager to learn.
cons: Students complain about other Professors.   No communications between campuses.  Tenure issue such as other schools and lots of politics.

review_title: Tri-C a great place to believe in and work.
pros: Education is something I think is very important... especially college for the first generation.. which is the bulk of most CCC students
cons: I have to travel an hour each way to get to work.  It's political.  And works starts at 8:30.

review_title: It's a wonderful workplace, love my job, I just wish they'd give me full-time and advancement opportunities!
pros:
Great pay
flexible scheduling
great atmosphere
great co-workers
casual dress code
same calendar vacations and holidays as school district 
free classes
use of recreational facilities free!
cons:
primarily part-time employment
you have to pay for parking
not enough parking spaces 
limited benefits
There are few downsides great!

review_title: Wish I could give zero stars
pros: They talk a good game and pass levies to line the pockets of administrators
cons: In my 20+ years I documented and tried to disclose that: They fire anyone who discovers what is really going on. They get employees to turn on one another. They have hired dozens of administrators who have been driven out of previous positions at other institutions. They fund programs that have marginal student impact (ie JazzFest) but which they can give VIP's perks and photo ops. These programs use (and lose) tens of thousands of dollars in tax-payer money.

pros: Good benefits and great PTO structure. Tuition reimbursement is great, nice program to improve employees health and wellbeing. Good salary.
cons: Tons of red tape and very political. You have to play the game to get ahead. Almost zero company culture. Can experience conflict when dealing with management vs faculty.

pros: Smart, Innovative and Student Centered (for the most part) staff, friendly group of people, good benefits and paid time off
cons: High volume workload, high expectations for some (not for other), unbalanced pay scales, high-stress, fast-paced

pros: Dedicated employees, focused on educating students
cons:
Micro-management, particularly by former college president Jerry Sue Thorton; constant interference by the college Foundation;
 not transparent to students, faculty and taxpayers; wasteful of tax dollars in awarding contracts to friends and supportors rather  than lowesr bid.

pros:
They will lie to you for so long that you will believe them. They will have you so convinced that you won't realize you are destroying the careers of their targeted employees.
They help 10% of their students very well, but at the cost of the other students and taxpayers.
cons: Their slogan is "Where futures begin." which is true for about 3 to 4 thousand of their 50K+ students, but it should be "Where futures are damaged or destroyed" for their employees.

pros: State of the art educational environment. Tuiton coverage for employees.
cons: No uniform administrative policy/practice. No comprehensive on-boarding for new hires. Tri-C has its own culture which requires an extensive on-boarding process that is not in place. You are on your own!

pros: People are great...work conditions great...community was warm and inviting...facilities are amazing...very pleasant work environment
cons: Too bureaucratic to respond to individual concerns or areas of improvement that need to be addressed to improve work experience...

job_title: Adjunct Clinical Instructor in Moreland Hills, OH
pros: Very flexible and accomodating. Collegiate atmosphere. Offers educational and training sessions. Great pay and fantastic benefits even for contract employees.
cons: You have to be very self motivated and be able to work independently. Also a lot of ongoing requirements and unnessesary paperwork.

pros:
Decent pay
Opportunities for advancement 
Wide range of job categories 
Good benefits 
Doing good for the community
cons:
Office politics
Union vs non-union disparities

job_title: Laboratory Assistant (Biology) in Highland Hills, OH
pros: Very low stress level. Friendly environment all around. Management is very involved in making sure that employees are satisfied. Part-timers get holiday pay.
cons: Sometimes very slow, with a lot of down-time. Part-timers do not get shift premium. Somewhat of a boy's club.

pros:
Working with wonderful people from a variety of different cultures.
Management in the TLC was excellent, they listened to concerns from the employees and worked with us to make things better.
Advancement opportunities.
cons: Only part-time hours in the TLC.

review_title: customer service learning commons at cuyahoga community college
job_title: Customer Service Learning Commons in Highland Hills, OH
pros:
Union position
starting pay is $15.47
cons:
Must apply for full time positions. No  promotions 
No vacation,  or sick time pay.
No paid vacation.

pros:
Encouraged to contribute 

Great work environment

Contributions are respected and appreciated
cons:
Lower pay than the industry standard

Change is slow

Many levels of approval with relatively minor decisions

pros: Tri-C has a very diverse culture and a wide variety of course offerings in every career field.
cons: Everything is positive at Tri-C.

review_title: Not a perfect place but who is perfect

pros: Flexible, positive work environment, well structured

review_title: Overseer for the Human Resources Policies and Procedures at Cuyahoga Community College. Ensuring clarity and efficient c
job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Cleveland, OH

cons: The managerial structure and the employees inability to leave their personal lives out of the workplace

pros: The students and the environment. Great benefits. Work environment is healthy.
cons: People in management positions that are there because of seniority (or union) rather than management skills.

pros:
Well known company
Free classes for current employees and their children
Lots of activities and events
cons:
Hiring process is long
Issues with payroll when changing titles or direct deposit information
Large payroll deduction applied to OPERS

pros: I feel like they have the same values as I do. I enjoy working with students and staff to help them learn and grow!
cons: None at this current time.

job_title: Senior Summer Camp Counselor in Cleveland, OH
pros: very open to diversity, super flexible work, and understanding administration
cons: location of the campus is in a pretty bad part of the city.

pros: Students, colleagues by and large good.
cons: Far too many administrators creating extra work for too few full time faculty. Too much dependence on part time faculty.

pros: CCC u s very good in its support of adjuncts.  They provide needed resources as well as paid professional development opportunities.
cons: Very difficult to get a full time position.

review_title: Truly a great place to work for
job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Highland Hills, OH
pros: Great people, warm, welcoming environment, and it was nice having a labor union there.
cons: none.  It is good and I am happy there.

pros: From the President down to the hourly workers these employees are real easy to work with.
cons: Not enough employees in our department.

pros:
Helping students succeed and assisting them with their issues is always an accomplishment
Great president at metro campus
cons: Not much chance for professional development and advancing yourself.

pros: People are helpful. Money is great. Fantastic organization for which to work.
cons: Driving all the way to Brunswick and getting lost on the Western campus :)

pros: Students usually want to learn. Fellow staff are supportive.
cons: Very low pay, as with most adjunct jobs.

review_title: Good place to work while finishing your degree.

pros: Pay, Hours, Educational Opportunity Nice Facillity
cons: Littile opportunity for advancement.  Union menbership is required.

pros: Flexibility and independence. That's about it...
cons: Lack of stability, risk of classes being cancelled at short notice, low pay and no benefits.

pros: Job provides good Flexibility with Schedule and Running your Course
cons: Hard to Advance and Plan per Semester

review_title: Working at Tri-C is like working with your family!
pros: Tri-C offers Competitive Salary to their employees
cons: Tri-C is a free-will employer.

pros: You get to meet new people from various backgrounds! It's a great opportunity.
cons: You cannot work more than 20 hours a week.

pros: Great people to work with

pros: Diversity, Good work culture, Dynamic, Progressive, and Good work atmosphere

pros:

pros: good people, good work, friendly and hospitable all around

pros: Laquodra Simmons (Supervisor, Academic Student Services)

pros: Great students. Enjoy the work.

pros: decent salaries, and good benefits
cons: They fire people every spring whether they are poor performers or not, leadership changes every year there is no consistency in leadership or staff from year to year.
